            Thanks for visiting!
            Welcome to my personal site! I am a mixed methods researcher working in education research at foundry10, a philanthropic educational research . Throughout my career I’ve worked as a qualitative, quantitative, and mixed-methods scientist in education and health research, and my work has consistently focused on developing tools to document people’s experiences in practical contexts. Check out a smattering of my projects on my Projects tab.
            Let’s collaborate!
            Do you want to geek out over measurement, coding, or group learning? Interested in having me talk at your organization or group? Do you have an idea how we could work together? Email me!

articles.title: Projects
articles.contents:
I’m a mixed methods researcher with a large toolbox. This page showcases some of the methods I’ve used.
Experimental user experience research
 I was the research lead for an experimental study looking at engagement, empathy, and narrative with commercial virtual reality experiences. I lead experimental design, data collection, and analysis for the study. We presented the results of this study at GDC 2018, a prominent game developer conference, and at CHI 2018, a leading conference on computer-human interaction.

Video presentation from GDC 2018 and slide deck

Article in CHI Proceedings
Usability testing for products in development
I designed usability and feasibility research for a prototype web application to help teachers and school administrators evaluate the impact of esports in schools. The usability data helped our client earn a Phase II Small Business Innovation Research grant.
Competitive analysis
I was the project lead for a study driving internal strategy for a mid-sized pharmaceutical company’s existing products for a psycho-neurological condition, with the intention of understanding the product experience from the patient’s perspective. My study activities included literature review, facilitation of an internal workshop defining company’s needs, interviews with clinical key opinion leaders, interviews with patients, analysis (qualitative and quantitative segmentation and comparison), industry presentations, and facilitation of an internal workshop outlining results.
Cluster analysis
 While technology use in schools is fairly widespread, there is a clear ‘usage gap’, where some teachers use technology for student creation, exploration, and collaboration, while others primarily use technology for lower-level uses such as passive media consumption and test-taking. Foundry10 collected survey responses from teachers across Washington State, identified distinct teacher personas based on their use of technology, and made recommendations for targeted teacher professional development. My role for this project was survey development, analysis, and writing. Preprint - article under review.
Ethnography and network analysis
 In collaboration with Young Women Empowered (Y-WE), a young women’s leadership camp, foundry10 conducts service design research. I analyze ethnographic and network data to study year-over-year outcomes in community building, staff experience, and support structures.

Poster presentation - Links between social support and relationship quality in a group mentoring context

Qualitative article - “Here I can just be myself”: How youth and adults collaboratively develop an identity-safe community across difference

Demo slide deck showing how network analysis can be used for program evaluation.
Survey development
I was the project lead at Health Research Associates for the PRO Consortium’s Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) study, a multi-sponsor effort to develop a lung cancer symptom inventory that can be used to support labeling claims. Through 2016, I managed the study’s literature review, protocol development, qualitative research, item generation, electronic product development (through a 3rd-party vendor), report writing, and dissemination (example posters here and here).

articles.title: Publications & Presentations
articles.contents:
Selected Peer-Reviewed Publications
[under review] Scanlon M, Castaneda LM, Wicks D. From access to implementation: describing teacher profiles in their uses of technology.
Bindman, S.W., Sobel, K., Behbakht, S., Divanji, R., Shahn, E., Scanlon, M. (2021). “Let’s draw chocolate milk together”: Supports and challenges for families’ joint engagement with artistic tablet apps. In Proceedings of IDC ’21: ACM Interaction Design and Children conference, June 26-30, 2021. Athens, Greece. ACM, New York, NY, USA.
Rubin, J, Scanlon M, Cechony A, Chen K (2021). “Here I can just be myself”: How youth and adults collaboratively develop an identity-safe community across difference. Journal of Community Psychology.
Bonny JW, Scanlon M, Castaneda LM (2020). Variations in Psychological Factors and Experience-Dependent Changes in Team-Based Video Game Performance. Intelligence, Volume 80, May–June 2020.
Bindman SW, Castaneda LM, Scanlon M, & Cechony A (2018, April). Am I a Bunny?: The Impact of High and Low Immersion Platforms and Viewers’ Perceptions of Role on Presence, Narrative Engagement, and Empathy during an Animated 360° Video. In Proceedings of the 2018 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (p. 457). ACM.
Scanlon M, Swanson T, Darvasi P, & Jenson J (2017, August). The first door: gender, authority and choice in The Stanley Parable. In Proceedings of the 12th International Conference on the Foundations of Digital Games (p. 37). ACM.
Bushnell D, Martin M, Scanlon M, Chen T, Chau D, Viswanathan H. Equivalence and measurement properties of an electronic version of the Psoriasis Symptom Inventory. Qual Life Res 23(3): 897-906, 2014.
Scanlon M, Wassink AB (2010). Using acoustic trajectory information in studies of merger. In Penn Working Papers in Linguistics 16.2 (Selected papers from NWAV 38).
Scanlon M, Wassink AB (2010). African American English in Urban Seattle: Accommodation and intra-speaker variation in the Pacific Northwest. American Speech 85(2), 205-224.
Selected Peer-Reviewed Presentations
Scanlon M (2021). Social support in group mentoring: A Network analysis of in-person and remote formats. Presentation at Society for Research in Child Development, April 2021.
Scanlon M, Cechony A (2021). Links between social support and relationship quality in a group mentoring context. Presentation at Society of Research on Adolescence, March 2021.
Scanlon M (2019). Teamwork-based developmental outcomes in student-led high school dance. Presentation at Society of Research on Child Development, Baltimore, Maryland, March 23, 2019.
Scanlon M, Shahn E, Cechony A (2019). Group influences on adolescent identity development in a creative context. Presentation at the 26th Annual Meeting of the International Society for Research on Identity (ISRI), Naples, Italy, May 14, 2019.
Scanlon M, Cechony A, & Shahn E (2019). Cognitive interviewing for scale validation: An examination of the ISI-5. Presentation at the 26th Annual Meeting of the International Society for Research on Identity (ISRI), Naples, Italy, May 14, 2019.
Scanlon M, Castaneda L (2019). Teacher perspectives on a hybrid approach to elementary STEM PD. Presentation at International Society for Teacher Education conference, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, June 25, 2019.
Castaneda L, Scanlon M (2018). Who am I? Role and Narrative in 360 video. Presentation at Game Developers Conference (GDC), San Francisco, CA, March 19-23, 2018.
Setyawan J, Scanlon M, Grebla R, McCarrier KP, Supina D, Pawaskar M, Martin M (2016). Qualitative assessment of patient-perceived impact of ADHD in adults. Presentation at Psych Congress.
Scanlon M, McCarrier KP, Coons SJ, Martin ML, Campbell AK, DeBusk K, Lungershausen J, Kaschinski D, Arduino JM, Liepa AM. Incorporating the patient’s voice into instrument development: How do patients describe the impact of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) on their breathing? 22nd Annual Conference of the International Society for Quality of Life Research, Vancouver, BC, October 21-24, 2015.
Scanlon M, Martin ML, McCarrier KP, Wolfe M, Quintanar-Solares M (2013). Mapping relationships among pain descriptors used by patients: Evidence from qualitative interviews in four chronic pain conditions. Value in Health, 16(3), A31-A32.
Bushnell, DM, McCarrier KP, Scanlon M, Nelson DR, Martin ML, & Buesching DP (2013). Validation and psychometric evaluation of a health care orientation assessment. Value in Health, 16(3), A34.
Popular Press Coverage
“Nonprofit takes D&D digital to help kids who struggle socially, and to study its own impact.” Geekwire, 2020.
“What can Dota players teach us about human learning?” Dotabuff, 2016.
Academic Work
Dissertation: Stylistic variation in African American Language: Examining the social meaning of linguistic features in a Seattle community. 2020, University of Washington.
MA thesis: A social network study of a Seattle neighborhood. 2007, University of Washington.
